artefact: Expenses and benefits: meals for employees and directors

artefact.alternative_title: Employers' tax and reporting for meal expenses
artefact.overview: Tax and reporting rules for employers providing meals for employees and directors

parts.title: Overview
parts.body:
As an employer providing meals for your employees, you have certain tax, National Insurance and reporting obligations.

What’s included

What you have to report and pay depends on:

  • the value of the meals
  • if they’re in a workplace canteen open to all staff
  • if they take place on or off your premises
  • if they’re paid for through employee ‘accounts’ or vouchers

parts.title: What's exempt
parts.body:
You don’t have to report anything to HMRC or pay tax and National Insurance if you offer all your employees:

  • free or subsidised meals of a reasonable value at a workplace canteen
  • vouchers that cover the cost of buying these meals
  • vouchers worth up to 15p per day

If you offer these meals or vouchers under salary sacrifice or flexible remuneration arrangements (also known as ‘flexible benefit plans’), these won’t be exempt.

Free or subsidised meals for low-earning employees

You don’t have to pay or report on these meals for employees earning at a rate of less than £8,500 a year.

parts.title: What to report and pay
parts.body:
If the meals or vouchers you provide aren’t exempt, you may have to report them to HMRC. You may have to deduct and pay tax and National Insurance on the costs.

Free or subsidised meals that aren’t exempt

This includes meals that:

  • aren’t on a reasonable scale, eg elaborate meals with fine wines
  • are provided off-site but not at a canteen, eg at a restaurant
  • aren’t available to all staff, eg meals for directors only
  • provided under salary sacrifice or flexible remuneration arrangements (also known as ‘flexible benefit plans’)

If you provide these meals to employees earning at a rate of £8,500 a year or more, or directors, you’ll need to:

  • report on form P11D, section M
  • pay Class 1A National Insurance on the cost to you

Vouchers for meals outside the workplace

You need to report and pay on the cost of vouchers above 15p per day.

Who gets the benefit What to do What to deduct or pay
Employees earning at a rate of less than £8,500 a year Report on form P9D, section B Class 1 National Insurance on the cost above 15p per day through payroll
Employees earning at a rate of £8,500 or more a year Report on form P11D, section C Class 1 National Insurance on the cost above 15p per day through payroll
Directors Report on form P11D, section C Class 1 National Insurance on the cost above 15p per day through payroll

Other vouchers, cash allowances or employee accounts

If you provide any of the following, this counts as earnings:

  • vouchers that can be exchanged for either food or cash
  • cash allowances for meals
  • top-up payments to an employee’s account for workplace food and drink using a card or PIN system

For these costs, you’ll need to:

  • add the amount to the employee’s other earnings
  • deduct and pay PAYE tax and Class 1 National Insurance through payroll

parts.title: Technical guidance
parts.body:
The following guides contain more detailed information:

  • subsidised meals including canteen meals and working lunches

  • meal allowances

  • cash allowances for meals

  • non-cash vouchers: meals

  • canteen arrangements: when do they count as earnings?

  • canteen arrangements: no exemption from 6 April 2011 in cases of salary sacrifice or flexible remuneration
